results.title: Redfern Beach
results.creator_credit: Rachel Roberts, Catriona McKenzie and AFTRS
results.brief_description:
Max needs to choose between money and love. An old bagman gives Max a magic fishing lure. As colour begins to seep into his life, the choice becomes clear.
Cast features Michael Tuahine, Phaedra Nicolaidis, Nicholas Papademetriou and Tony Barry.

results.title: Great falls
results.creator_credit: AFTRS, Libby Porter and Yves Stening
results.brief_description:
Jackie and his father return from a duck shooting trip to find his mother preparing to leave home with a young Air Force officer. She tells Jackie that she wants “a less domestic life”. Jackie doesn’t really understand what has happened but he knows that these things do happen and that life goes on somehow. “… I thought to myself that my life had turned … it was something that happened
to you - I knew that - and it happened to me in this way now.” Based on the short story by Richard Ford.

results.title: A (Darren Almond)
results.brief_description:
Darren Almond’s film and video works create a tension between stillness and movement. The experience of place takes on a strong resonance in Almond’s minimalist but emotionally charged settings, which explore space, time and human subjectivity.

As an elemental ‘landscape simply made up of air, liquid and gas in different states’, Antarctica is a location that has long fascinated Almond. In early 2002, the artist was invited by Mission Antarctica to crew for a month around the Antarctic Peninsula. A is his response to that journey, in which Antarctica represents ‘the axis of time and space, the axis of everything’.

Almond’s haunting film envelopes the viewer in an abstract world, devoid of human presence. Skimming the crystalline surfaces of the ice islands, A slowly reveals delicate variations in the landscape as ice meets water and sky. The near-silence of Antarctica is matched with a dreamy score and the sampling of real sounds-cracks and rips in the ice-that Almond recorded on his journey. The visual and aural experience of A is as much an interior, psychological journey as an exterior one to the ‘end’ of the earth.

(SW 30.03.05)

results.title: Dolores from 10 to 10
results.brief_description:
Dolores from 10 to 10 is a multi-channel installation, adapted from Fusco and Ricardo Dominguez’s 12-hour performance at Kiasma in Helsinki, which was streamed live to the internet in 2001. The work refers to the true story of a maquiladora (assembly line) worker, falsely accused of unionizing workers at her plant. Locked in an office for 12 hours without food, water, or telephone access, she was coerced into signing a letter of resignation. Her lawsuit against her employers was eventually denied on the grounds that she had no ‘proof’.

Dolores from 10 to 10 is Fusco’s interpretation of this real-life internment and a re-construction of what might have been seen if there had been surveillance cameras in the office. Framed by the female labour situation in Mexico, Fusco highlights the inequalities of the relationship between women and technology across the world.

results.title: BIT Plane
results.brief_description:
The Bitplane video captures an aero-portrait of a richly mythologised territory - the Silicon Valley in California, home to the largest concentration of wealth in California since the Gold Rush. The Bitplane’s mission takes it deep into the heart of the Valley, to view the source and progress of the Information Age. Due to its tiny dimensions, the Bitplane is able to enter territory inaccessible to other aircraft.

One of the issues the Bitplane engages with on this reconnaissance flight is the threat of the camera to information space. Cameras are not permitted into the corporate research parks in teh Valley, according to the logic that visitors could steal intellectual property by taking photographs. This reveals an assumption that information is something you can photograph, a thing - not the product of a community or expertise or a social network of shared discourse but something you could steal with a camera.

From the Artist Statement provided for PROOF exhibition, Dec 2004.
